Today, as I continue to celebrate Black History Month, I am highlighting the incredible legacy of West Chester local Horace Pippin, a decorated World War I veteran, artist, and civil rights activist. During the war, Pippin served in the then-segregated U.S. Army as part of the all-Black Harlem Hellfighters infantry regiment. At the Battle of Sechault, Pippin was shot and later awarded the Purple Heart for his valor. After the war, he pursued his passion for art, creating pieces mixing his experiences as a soldier and a black man in segregated America. His works brought attention to the plight of African Americans and explored artistic avenues for resisting oppression during the civil rights movement. His pieces received national acclaim and have been displayed in the MoMa, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and the National Gallery of Art. I am thankful for his service to our country, his transformative contributions to our nation's artistic legacy, and his enduring advocacy for civil rights.

(The second photo is his painting of the West Chester Court House!)
